text:
PAUL MATSUDAIRA: The reason
why we want to sequence DNA

is for the simple
reason that DNA

contains the basic instruction
set for the basis of life.

Cells replicate on
their own, and in order

to replicate or make
copies of themselves,

they have to have
an instruction set.

And that instruction
set codes or encodes

for all of the
machinery that the cell
has to assemble and build.

The human genome is three
billion bases of DNA

which encodes for an incredibly
complicated machine, which

is ourselves, and we want
to know how that came to be
and what that represents.

And so that's all somehow
in that DNA sequence.

A simple way of thinking
about a DNA sequencer
is that it's a decoding machine.

The genome codes the information
in a string of DNA bases,

and the trick is
to identify what's

the order of those bases in
a strand or a piece of DNA.

What the DNA sequencer does is
it takes a sample of DNA that's
been fragmented into pieces.
It sucks up those samples.

It's a multi-headed
pipetter, 96 pipette tips.

It sucks up the sample, moves
over to where the samples are

actually introduced into the
gel, which is the working
component of the machine.

And then, after
that, the samples

are separated by
electrophoresis and then

the different
pieces are detected

by a fluorescence-based
detector,

and then the signals are
processed and converted
into one of the four DNA bases.

So it's a machine that
decodes the chemical sequence

into a four-base
digital sequence.

What we're trying to refine
with the DNA sequencer is

trying to improve
its performance,
make it a much better machine.

It's going to be commercially
available in the next year.

But rather than improving
the DNA sequencer itself,

we want to improve
the technologies that

are associated with how to
prepare a sample for DNA

sequencing, as well as take what
we've learned about building

machines such as
ours and building

other kinds of machines
designed to study

other kinds of
biological problems.

Bioengineering is just
breaking open as a field.

It's breaking open because
biology in itself, which

is the scientific basis
for bioengineering,

is undergoing a major change
or a major revolution,

caused mainly because we were
able to have sequenced genomes
now.

But now, we want to
know what that means

and how we can use
that information,

and that's where
bioengineers come in.
